title: Are sunscreens a new environmental risk associated with coastal tourism?
abstract: The world coastal-zone population and coastal tourism are expected to grow during this century. Associated with that, there will be an increase in the use of sunscreens and cosmetics with UV-filters in their formulation, which will make coastal regions worldwide susceptible to the impact of these cosmetics. Recent investigations indicate that organic and inorganic UV-filters, as well as many other components that are constituents of the sunscreens, reach the marine environment-directly as a consequence of water recreational activities and/or indirectly from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) effluents. Toxicity of organic and inorganic UV filters has been demonstrated in aquatic organism. UV-filters inhibit growth in marine phytoplankton and tend to bioaccumulate in the food webs. These findings together with coastal tourism data records highlight the potential risk that the increasing use of these cosmetics would have in coastal marine areas. Nevertheless, future investigations into distribution, residence time, aging, partitioning and speciation of their main components and by-products in the water column, persistence, accumulation and toxicity in the trophic chain, are needed to understand the magnitude and real impact of these emerging pollutants in the marine system.

abstract.text: The world coastal-zone population and coastal tourism are expected to grow during this century. Associated with that, there will be an increase in the use of sunscreens and cosmetics with UV-filters in their formulation, which will make coastal regions worldwide susceptible to the impact of these cosmetics. Recent investigations indicate that organic and inorganic UV-filters, as well as many other components that are constituents of the sunscreens, reach the marine environment-directly as a consequence of water recreational activities and/or indirectly from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) effluents. Toxicity of organic and inorganic UV filters has been demonstrated in aquatic organism. UV-filters inhibit growth in marine phytoplankton and tend to bioaccumulate in the food webs. These findings together with coastal tourism data records highlight the potential risk that the increasing use of these cosmetics would have in coastal marine areas. Nevertheless, future investigations into distribution, residence time, aging, partitioning and speciation of their main components and by-products in the water column, persistence, accumulation and toxicity in the trophic chain, are needed to understand the magnitude and real impact of these emerging pollutants in the marine system.

body_text.text: Throughout the history of human beings, the sun has been an object of adoration and exploration. However, it was not only a focus of admiration. Since humans lost their covering of hair and exposed their skin to sunlight they have felt the need to protect themselves, either by wearing appropriated clothes or by using paints or powders. As far as we know, the ancients Egyptians were the first to use a kind of sunscreen made of olive oil, and this was also the case in Greece and Rome. However, it was at the end of the nineteenth century when the first scientific research into sunscreen protection was reported. From 1887 to 1934 several compounds that can be used as filters of the ultraviolet radiation (UV-filters) were discovered and in 1928 the first sunscreen was commercially available. It was during these years when international cosmetic companies were born (e.g. L'Oreal, Delial, Piz Buin, Coppertone, etc.) and when sunscreens became widely used among the general population (Rik Roelandts, 2008; Urbach, 2001) . After the World War II, tanned skin became synonymous with good health and beauty in western cultures.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Nowadays, among different cosmetic products, sunscreens have been shown to give the most effective protection against ultraviolet (UV) radiation damage (Diffey, 2005) . Short exposure (between 5 and 10 min) to UV radiation has therapeutic effects, i.e. it improves the production of vitamin D and this will increase calcium absorption, therefore preventing rickets in children and osteoporosis in adults. However, longer exposures can cause severe damage to skin such as skin aging, the erythema (sunburn) and/or melanoma (Holick, 2004) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Three segments compose the sun care market: sun protection, after sun, and self-tanning. This market increases every year worldwide due to the awareness of the risk associated with the sun exposure (What's Hot around the Globe: Insights on Personal Care Products. Global Service Studies Website, 2007) . Cosmetic companies flood the market every year with new products, formulations and terms like "nanoparticles", "waterproof" or "broad spectrum" that generates confusion among users, who are calling for a more effective sunscreen (Kamerow, 2014) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Coastal and marine tourism is the fastest growing sector of the global tourism industry (Hall, 2001; Honey and Krantz, 2007) . The number of tourists grew from 463 million in 1992 to 763 million in 2004 worldwide and it is expected that reach 1.56 billion in 2020 (Honey and Krantz, 2007) . The growth of this sectordemands infrastructural development (hotels, ports, second homes, marinas, etc.), water activities and sports (i.e. recreational fishing, yachting, diving, etc.) necessary to accommodate and entertain the large number of visitors to the coastal areas. The impact caused by these activities on the coastal environment has been reported in several studies (Davenport and Davenport, 2006; Gormsen, 1997; Hall, 2001) . Thus, environmental degradation and pollution (e.g. by yachts fuel, littering, seasonal increase of terrestrial runoff, etc.), destruction of habitats (e.g. destruction of coral reefs due to excessive visitations, disturbance of nearshore aquatic life, etc.), or damage to sand-dune ecosystems (e.g. lost of sandy beaches due to onshore construction), are some of the impacts of coastal tourism. Despite that coastal tourism is the fastest growing sector in the world and the sunscreen market increases every year, the implications of sunscreens as a source of new chemicals into the coastal marine system have been poorly evaluated.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Sunscreen cosmetic can be defined as: "any cosmetic product containing UV-filters in its formulation in order to protect the skin from the solar deleterious UV-light, avoiding or minimizing the damage that this radiation might cause on human health" (Salvador and Chisvert, 2005) . Therefore, the most important components of the sunscreens are the UV-filters: substances with a range of light absorption in the range of UVA (400-320 nm), and/or UVB (320-280 nm), and with nearly no absorption of visible radiation (Díaz-Cruz and Barceló, 2009) .
body_text.section: Main components of sunscreens

body_text.text: Concentration limits that can be used in sunscreen formulations depend on the different regulations worldwide (Table 1) . UV-filters can be organic (classified into different families: i.e. benzophenone derivatives, salicylates, cinnamates, camphor derivatives, p-aminobenzoic acid and its derivatives, etc. (Chisvert and Salvador, 2007) ), or inorganic (with only two allowed compounds: titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) and zinc oxide (ZnO)). General usage of these inorganic components in the formulation of sunscreens is in the form of nanoparticles (nano-TiO and nano-ZnO, with size around ≤100 nm) because they give an effective protection and they do not whiten the skin (Osterwalder et al., 2014 ).
body_text.section: Main components of sunscreens

body_text.text: Because of its photocatalytic properties, TiO 2 nanoparticles used in sunscreens are coated with aluminum oxide or silica to prevent the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Jansen et al., 2013a) . Commonly, ZnO in sunscreens are in the form of nanorods while TiO are nanoparticles in the rutile structure (Lewicka et al., 2011) . L'Oreal Group was the first company that in August 1993 patented the use of nanoparticles of metal oxides as ingredients in sunscreens (Forestier et al., 1995) . The action mode of both types of UV-filters is different: while the organic absorbs a specific wavelength, the inorganic ones can give a boarder spectrum protection due to their triple action mode: reflection, scattering and absorption of the UV radiation (Manaia et al., 2013) . Sunscreens are usually comprised of one or more of these UV-filters: organic, inorganic or a mixture of both. This combination increases the protection giving broad-spectrum sunscreens.
body_text.section: Main components of sunscreens

body_text.text: Emollients and emulsifiers are present in an elevated percentage in the composition of sunscreens. Emollients play a triple role in the sunscreens composition: they enable solubilization of some UV-filters (i.e. benzoate esters), photostabilization of unstable UV-filters (i.e. butyloctyl salicylates), and they enhance sensorial feeling in terms of spreading, greasiness, stickiness, etc. (i.e. dicaprylyl carbonate) (Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Some emollients can also have an inherent UV absorption that increases the broad spectrum of protection. Emulsifiers are amphiphilic molecules that reduce interfacial tension between two immiscible liquids playing an important role in the stability of the emulsion, consistency, skin feel and care properties of the formulation (Al-Bawab and Friberg, 2006; Plass et al., 2001 ). The emulsifier system defines the emulsion type: traditionally, oil-in-water (O/W) or waterin-oil (W/O) system (Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Anionic emulsifiers such as alkyl phosphates (i.e. potassium cetyl phosphate) are commonly used to stabilize O/W emulsions and allow the incorporation of inorganic UV-filters (Miller et al., 1999; Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Other emulsifiers such as PEG-30 dipolyhydroxysterate, stabilize W/O systems and improve the water resistance of the sunscreens and may incorporate lipophilic-coated inorganic UV-filters. Besides this, new formulations of sunscreens became popular among consumers: oils, water-based and hydroalcoholic lotions and microemulsions, also called easy-touse sunscreens (Chisvert and Salvador, 2007) .
body_text.section: Main components of sunscreens

body_text.text: In sunscreen composition we can find many other ingredients such as rheology modifiers (thickeners as glycerin or fatty acids), filmforming agents as acrylates copolymer or silicones, organic UV stabilizers as benzotriazole derivatives, sensory enhancers that improve the skin feeling (i.e. silica, nylon-based compounds, etc.) and in some cases antioxidants such as vitamin C and vitamin E, which are included to reduce the oxidative stress generated by ROS formation via UV radiation. Moreover, other photoprotective agents in sunscreens provide protection from sunburn and also reduce inflammation and oxidative damage; as for example carotenoids, polyphenols, algae extracts, nicotiamide (amide form of vitamin B 3 ), vitamin A (incorporated as retinyl palmitate), selenium (in the forms of selenium sulfide or Lselenomethionine, that increase the threshold radiation dose that may produce sunburn), etc. Jansen et al., 2013b; Osterwalder et al., 2014) .
body_text.section: Main components of sunscreens

body_text.text: Although the development of sensitive analytical methodologies over the last number of years has allowed the determination of UVfilters and its derivatives in different environmental compartments, information about the presence and concentrations of these components in the marine environment is scarce.
body_text.section: Analytical methodologies for the determination of UV-filters in environmental samples

body_text.text: There are 50 organic compounds allowed by different legislations to be used as UV-filters in sunscreen composition (Table 1) . However, only 16 have been analyzed in environmental matrices (Table 2) , therefore the environmental implications of organic UV-filters cannot be completely estimated.
body_text.section: Organic UV-filters

body_text.text: Many analytical methodologies have been developed for the determination of organic UV-filters in different natural matrices (Díaz-Cruz and Barceló, 2009; Salvador and Chisvert, 2005) . Due to the very low concentration of organic UV-filters in the environment (ranging from pM to nM), a pre-concentration step is necessary previous to the analysis (mostly based on extraction and microextraction procedures such as pressurized liquid extraction, ionic liquid-based single drop microextraction, stir bar sorptive extraction, dispersive liquid-liquid microextraction, solid-phase extraction and microextraction, micelle mediated extraction-solvent back extraction, non-porous membraneassisted liquid-liquid extraction, etc.). Pre-concentrated analytes are usually separated and quantified by chromatographic techniques coupled with mass spectrometry detection (LC-MS/MS, GC-MS/MS, UHPLC-MS/MS, etc.) (Benedé et al., 2014a,b; Bratkovics and Sapozhnikova, 2011; Cuderman and Heath, 2007; Gago-Ferrero et al., 2011a Giokas et al., 2004 Giokas et al., , 2005 Gómez et al., 2009; Lambropoulou et al., 2002; Magi et al., 2012; Nguyen et al., 2011; Oliveira et al., 2010; Pedrouzo et al., 2009 Pedrouzo et al., , 2010 Rodil et al., 2009a,b,c; Rodil and Moeder, 2008; Sánchez-Brunete et al., 2011; Tarazona et al., 2010; Trenholm et al., 2008; Vidal et al., 2010; Wick et al., 2010) . Passive sampling devices are sometimes used to sample over longer periods of time. For example, the use of semipermeable membrane devices (SPMDs) were used in Swiss lakes and rivers over three weeks (Balmer et al., 2005; Buser et al., 2005) and during a cruise across the Pacific Ocean (Goksøyr et al., 2009) . Table 1 Permitted UV-filters according to the different regulations (Source: (Ahmed, 2008)
body_text.section: Organic UV-filters

body_text.text: Some analytical approaches have also been proposed for the determination of titanium dioxide nanoparticles as the main inorganic UVfilters in the marine environment. Analytical methodologies for the analysis of nanoparticles in environmental matrices imply separation methods (e.g. size-exclusion chromatography, hydrodynamic chromatography, counter-current chromatography, electrophoresis and capillary electrophoresis or field-flow fractionation), electron microscopy techniques (e.g. transmission electron microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, scanning tunnel microscopy and atomic force microscopy), scattering (dynamic light scattering) and spectroscopy techniques (nuclear magnetic resonance and X-ray spectroscopy) (Farré and Barceló, 2012; López-Heras et al., 2014) . In addition to the composition, these techniques provide information about concentration, size distribution, crystallographic structure and morphology. Because of the lack of accurate methodologies for the analysis of nanomaterials in the complex matrix of seawater, concentration of total Ti 4+ after acid digestion is often reported (Luo et al., 2014) . In this regard, a new procedure for the determination of Ti 4+ in environmental samples has been reported (Sánchez-Quiles et al., 2013) .
body_text.section: Inorganic UV-filters

body_text.text: Analysis of nanoparticles in marine environmental samples is limited due to the lack of reliable methods for its detection and quantification. In addition to the electronic microscopy and particle size techniques (such as hydrodynamic chromatography or electrophoresis), new methods based on asymmetrical flow field-flow fractionation coupled to ICP-MS (asFlFFF-ICP-MS) and single particle ICP-MS (SP-ICP-MS) have been reported for analysis of nano-TiO 2 in different environmental samples (Laborda et al., 2014; Lee et al., 2014; López-Heras et al., 2014) . Although these methods have demonstrated to be useful for analysis of nanoparticles they have not been tested in seawater samples.
body_text.section: Inorganic UV-filters

body_text.text: In parallel with the development of new analytical methodologies for the quantification of UV-filters in environmental matrices, ecotoxicological assays have been performed in aquatic organisms in order to establish its toxicity thresholds.
body_text.section: Sunscreens in the environment

body_text.text: UV-filters can reach the marine environment mainly by two different ways: directly as consequence of water recreational activities and/ or indirectly from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) effluents (Díaz-Cruz and Barceló, 2009; . Some studies have indicated that there is a direct relationship between beachgoer affluence and the amounts of sunscreens components released into the seawater (Tovar-Sánchez et al., 2013) , mountain lakes and rivers (Balmer et al., 2005; Poiger et al., 2004) . On the other hand, WWTP effluents could affect areas of high tourism activities. Application of sunscreens not only implies direct release, but also indirect release through domestic sewage . Daily activities like showering, laundering or even urinating are sources of sunscreen components discharged to the WWTP where they are not completely removed (Li et al., 2007) .
body_text.section: Sources of UV-filters in the marine environment

body_text.text: It is expected that, on the skin, UV-filters should be photostable under sunlight, however in aqueous media (e.g. seawater) can undergo change and form undesirable by products that could compromise their UV absorption properties (Santos et al., 2012) . Organic UV-filters can degrade in different ways: photolysis and photoisomerization, break down by products in WWTP or can be metabolized by kidneys after topical application and their metabolites can be excreted in the urine (Díaz-Cruz et al., 2008) .
body_text.section: Photolysis, photoreactivity and phototoxicity of UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Photodegradation processes may occur in surface waters by direct and/or indirect photolysis. Direct photolysis implies the selfdecomposition after the organic UV-filters absorb UV radiation, whereas indirect photolysis involves different photosensitizers agents such as dissolved organic matter (DOM), reactive oxygen species (ROS), or another inorganic substances (e.g. nitrates, bicarbonates, NaCl or TiO 2 ) (Giokas and Vlessidis, 2007) . Photoisomerization of some organic UVfilters may occur in natural waters, which is the case with 4-methyl bencylidene camphor (4-MBC) (Buser et al., 2005) , whereas others like benzophenone-3 (BZ-3) suffers demethylation to produce benzophenone-1 (BZ-1) (Kim and Choi, 2014) . In the presence of DOM and UV radiation, para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) may produces the di(tri)-polymerization of the radical intermediates as the dominant products (Zhou et al., 2013) . Octyl methoxycinnamate (OMC) can undergo photoisomerization, photodegradation and photodimerization to obtain several dimer and cyclodimers isomers (MacManus-Spencer et al., 2011) . In chlorinated waters (e.g. swimming pools) organic UVfilters may produce several chlorinated organic compounds known as disinfection by-products, linked to adverse health effects in humans (i.e. respiratory diseases) (Santos et al., 2012) . However, the environmental toxicity and persistence of the by-products of organic UVfilters, after exposition to UV radiation and chemical reaction with chlorine, remain to be explored.
body_text.section: Photolysis, photoreactivity and phototoxicity of UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: It has been demonstrated that under UV radiation some organic UVfilters (e.g. BZ-3, octocrylene (OCR), OMC, phenylbenzimidazole sulphonic acid (PBS), PABA, etc.) can generate ROS in both, over the skin and in aqueous solution (O − , OH, H 2 O 2 , etc.) (Allen et al., 1996; Hanson et al., 2006; Inbaraj et al., 2002; Sánchez-Quiles and Tovar-Sánchez, 2014; Serpone et al., 2002) . Sánchez-Quiles and Tovar-Sánchez (2014) demonstrated that sunscreens might increase the concentration of H O 2 up to 270 nM/day in the waters of a Mediterranean Beach. This oxidizing specie can damage lipids, proteins and DNA and it can generate high stress levels in marine organisms (Lesser, 2006, and references therein) . Other studies have demonstrated that inorganic UV-filters (i.e. TiO 2 ) can also generate ROS, which is toxic for the marine phytoplankton (Miller et al., 2012) . Several studies agree that the toxicity of nano-TiO is produced by its photochemical properties under solar radiation, that depend on the radiation intensity, the crystalline structure and the concentration of the nanoparticles (Hund-Rinke and Simon, 2006; Li et al., 2014; Mansfield et al., 2015) . Even though nanoparticles are usually covered with an inert coating layer to avoid its photoreactivity, this layer is dissolved in aquatic environments after being released from sunscreens (Botta et al., 2011; Labille et al., 2010) . A recently published review about phototoxicity of nano-TiO 2 calculates the "phototoxicity ratio" obtained with experiments conducted in the presence and absence of sunlight and concludes that phototoxicity of nano-TiO 2 , under solar radiation, is specially harmful for the crustacean Cladocera (Jovanović, 2015) .
body_text.section: Photolysis, photoreactivity and phototoxicity of UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: The use of sunscreens has become popular since the second half of 20th century. As a consequence of the increasing coastal global tourism (Hall, 2001; Honey and Krantz, 2007) and the use of sunscreens (What's Hot around the Globe: Insights on Personal Care Products. Global Service Studies Website, 2007) the interest of researchers in the determination of organic UV-filters in different environmental and urban compartments has increased in the last years ( Fig. 1 ).
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Because WWTP cannot efficiently remove high concentrations of the organic UV-filters (Li et al., 2007) , and in spite of the natural degradation that occurs in the environment, these compounds are present in effluents and freshwaters that ultimately reach the sea. The first analyses of organic UV-filters in swimming pool and seawater samples were carried out in 2002 (Lambropoulou et al., 2002) . With less than 50 peer-reviewed scientific articles published to date (Fig. 1) , Spain is the country which has the highest number of research investigations (16 research articles) involving the analysis of environmental levels of organic UV-filters, following by Swiss and Germany (6 and 5 research articles, respectively).
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Sunscreen organic components have been determined in seawater, freshwaters (rivers and lakes), WWTP influents and effluents, swimming pools, urban groundwater and even in tap water (Table 3 ). The concentration of many organic UV-filters in seawater (i.e. BZ-1, BZ-3, homosalate (HS), isoamyl p-methoxycinnamate (IMC), OCR, octyl dimethyl PABA (ODP), OMC and octyl salicylate (OS)) are present in the same magnitude, or even higher, than those measured in WWTP's influents and effluents (Table 3 ). Significant concentrations of organic UVfilters have been also measured in lake (i.e. 4-MBC: 1140 ± 50 ng L − 1 ; Butyl methoxydibenzoylmethane (BDM): 2431 ± 22 ng L −1 ; OCR: 4381 ± 539 ng L −1 and OMC: 3009 ± 206 ng L −1 .) and swimming pool waters (BZ-3: 3.3 μg L − 1 ; ODP: 2.1 μg L − 1 and IMC: 700 ± 300 ng L −1 ) ( Table 3 ). These data confirm that the direct release of these compounds into the environment is quantitatively significant and point out recreational waters as an important source of organic UV-filters in the environment. In addition, Goksøyr et al. (2009) reported concentrations of organic UV-filters in open waters of the Pacific Ocean, providing evidence of the persistence and wide dispersion of these components in the marine environment.
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Organic UV-filters have also been analyzed in solid samples such as sediments, beach sand, soils and sludge (Table 4) . In marine sediments maximum concentrations ranged from 7.90 ng g −1 d.w. to 150 ng g −1 d.w. for 4-MBC and ODP, respectively. Tarazona et al. (2014) collected sand from four Spanish beaches and analyzed eight organic UV-filters. They found the maximum concentrations in the two most croweded beaches (ranged from 1.0 ± 0.1 ng g −1 d.w. to 25 ± 3 ng g −1 d.w. for BZ-3 and OCR, respectively.). The range in sediments collected from rivers is wider than in marine sediments (from 6.1 ± 0.3 ng g −1 to 2400 ng g −1 d.w. for benzophenone-6 (BZ-6) and OMC, respectively). Only OMC and OCR have been detected in lake sediments with concentrations ranged between 14 ± 4 − 34 ± 6 ng g −1 and 61 ± 5 − 93 ± 4 ng g −1 , respectively. The highest concentrations were found in sewage sludge; these concentrations can rise up to ng g −1 d.w. for 4-MBC, 18,740 ng g −1 d.w. for OCR and 27,700 ng g −1 d.w. for octyl triazone (OT) ( Table 4 ). The occurrence of these compounds in sediments could cause a potential risk to benthic organisms.
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Organic UV-filters have been found in tissues of natural populations of aquatic organisms such as mussels, crustacean, eels, fishes, marine mammals and aquatic birds (Table 5 ). Due to its lipophilicity these compounds tend to accumulate in muscle and adipose tissues of marine organisms (Gago-Ferrero et al., 2012) . Thus, elevated concentrations of OCR were found in the liver of Franciscana dolphin (Pontoporia blainvillei) from Brazil (up to 712 ng g − 1 lipid) (Gago-Ferrero et al., 2013a) or in mussels (Mytilus sp.) collected along the French coast (up to 7112 ng g −1 d.w.) (Bachelot et al., 2012) (Table 5 ), suggesting that bioaccumulation of organic UV-filters in the food webs may be happening.
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Many ecotoxicological studies have been done to assess the potential damage of sunscreens and their components. In vitro experiments have demonstrated that organic UV-filters might be toxic for some aquatic microorganisms. For example, Sieratowicz et al. 2011calculated the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50 ) of BZ-3, 3bencylidene camphor (3-BC) and 4-MBC for a freshwater phytoplankton specie Desmodesmus subspicatus (0.96 mg L − 1 , 6.99 mg L − 1 and 7.66 mg L −1 , respectively) in a 72 h culture experiment. More recently, Paredes et al. (2014) have calculated the toxicity according to the half maximal effective concentration (EC 50 ) in the specie of microalga Isochryris galbana concluding that toxicity decreases from BZ-3, OMC, 4-MBC and benzophenone-4 (BZ-4) with EC 50 of 13.87 ng mL −1 , 74.72 ng mL −1 , 171,45 ng mL −1 and N10,000 ng mL −1 , respectively. In the protozoan Tetrahymena thermophila BZ-3 and 4-MBC could inhibit the growth (EC 50 of 7.5 mg L −1 and 5.1 mg L −1 , respectively) in 24 h culture experiments (Gao et al., 2013) . The ecotoxicity of UV-filters in crustacean Daphnia magna showed after h that OMC was more toxic than 4-MBC, BZ-3, 3-BC and BZ-4 (EC 50 of 0.29-0.57 mg L −1 , 0.56-0.80 mg L −1 , 1.67-1.9 mg L −1 , 3.61 mg L −1 and 50 mg L −1 , respectively) (Fent et al., 2010a; Sieratowicz et al., 2011) .
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Some researchers having evaluated the toxicity of four UV-filters in marine invertebrates, Mytilus galloprovincialis (mussels), Paracentrotus lividus (sea urchins) and Siriella armata (crustacea), concluded the following: 4-MBC and OMC were the most toxics (EC 50 for 4-MBC ranged from 192.63 μg L − 1 in S. armata to 853.74 μg L −1 in P. lividus and 199.43 μg L − 1 in S. armata to 3118.18 μg L −1 in M. galloprovincialis for OMC), whereas BZ-4 presented the lowest toxicity (EC 50 higher than 10,000 μg L −1 in the three species) (Paredes et al., 2014) . Also OMC showed toxic effects on snails (lowest observed effect concentrations (LOEC) of 0.4 mg Kg −1 in Potamopyrgus antipodarum and 10 mg Kg −1 in Melanoides tuberculata) while BDM and OCR showed no effects (Kaiser et al., 2012) .
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Hormonal effects (estrogenic, antiestrogenic, androgenic and antiandrogenic activities) of some organic UV-filters have been extensively studied using in vitro test in human cells, fish and frogs (Díaz-Cruz and Barceló, 2009; Kim and Choi, 2014 and references therein). Different studies carried out in fish have demonstrated that concentrations of organic UV-filters may induce change in genes in hormonal pathways, for example concentrations in the order of μg L −1 of BZ-3, BZ-4 or OMC down-regulated the expression of genes involved in the sex hormone of Danio rerio (zebrafish) at two different life stages, eleuthero-embryos and adult (Blüthgen et al., 2012; Zucchi et al., 2011a, b) .
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of organic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Very little is known about the worldwide production of the two inorganic UV-filters (nano-TiO 2 and nano-ZnO). In accordance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), in 2005 the global production of nano-TiO was estimated at 2000 t and during the period 2006 − has been calculated at 5000 t per year (US EPA National Center for Environmental Assessment and Powers., n.d.). However, there are other estimations of this production, thus Piccinno et al. (2012) estimated, based on an industry survey, a global production of 550 to 5500 t per year. According to Aschberger et al. (2011) the estimated production is about 60,000 t per year. The global production of nano-ZnO was calculated also in several studies, thus while Piccinno et al. (2012) calculated a production between 55 and 550 t per year, Aschberger et al. (2011) estimated in 10,000 t per year the nano-ZnO production. It is believed that 60% of nano-TiO and 80% of nano-ZnO of the global production are used in cosmetic products (Piccinno et al., 2012) . These nanoparticles can reach the marine environment during their entire life cycle (i.e. production of nanoparticles, fabrication and use of products) via air deposition, WWTP effluents and/or direct release (Baker et al., 2014; Sun et al., 2014) . Once in the seawater they can interact with aquatic organisms in different ways: adsorption to the surface of microorganisms, cellular internalization, trapping by filter feeder organisms (e.g. bivalves), ingest by benthic fauna from the sediments or uptake by fish (Baker et al., 2014) . Sánchez-Quiles and Tovar-Sánchez (2014) estimated that in a touristic beach during a summer day about 4 kg of TiO nanoparticles could be released from sunscreens into seawater. Other authors suggest that recreational activities that take place at the Old Danube Lake may imply a consumption of sunscreen of 8.1 t per year, and estimated that 94.5 Kg of TiO per year may released in the lake waters (Gondikas et al., 2014) . In a more general estimation, Wong et al. (2010) calculated that around 250 t of nanoparticles could be potentially discharged from sunscreens into the coastal environment.
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of inorganic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: More than 200 studies provide evidence of the toxicity of nanoparticles in aquatic organisms and most of them (64%) were performed on fresh waters species, and only 14% were on salt water species (Minetto et al., 2014) . Miller et al. (2010) demonstrated that nano-ZnO produces inhibition growth in four species of marine phytoplankton with concentrations between 0.5 and 1.0 mg L −1 , while nano-TiO does not present any significant effects at these concentrations. Ma et al. (2012) demonstrated that phototoxicity of nano-TiO increased between 2 to 4 times under simulated solar radiation, being D. magna times more sensitive than fish Japanese medaka (Oryzias latipes). The effects of long-term exposure of cladoceran D. magna to nano-TiO 2 were studied over six generations showing that chronic exposure to 1.78 mg L − 1 of nano-TiO resulted in 100% mortality (Jacobasch et al., 2014) . A similar study in zebrafish (D. rerio) demonstrated that, after six months of exposure, nano-TiO was bioaccumulated in brain, gill, liver and heart, producing organ injury and mortality (Chen et al., 2011) .
body_text.section: Concentrations and toxicity of inorganic UV-filters in the environment

body_text.text: Sunscreens are a source of toxic chemicals into the environment, UV-filters and other components such are UV stabilizers (e.g. benzotriazole derivatives) have been analyzed in the tissues of marine organisms such are clams, oysters, gastropods and fish (Kim et al., 2011b; Nakata et al., 2009) and showed toxicity in some aquatic species such are the crustacean Daphnia pulex and the fish D. rerio (Fent et al., 2014; Kim et al., 2011a ), silicate (SiO ) and ammonium (NH 4 + )) in the coastal marine environment. Although the ecological significance of this input has not been evaluated yet, Tovar-Sánchez et al. (2013) suggest that it could enhance the primary production in the oligotrophic waters of the Mediterranean Sea.
body_text.section: The role of sunscreens as source of pollutants into coastal waters

body_text.text: A study carried out on a touristic beach indicates that both, a temporal (daily) and vertical (water column) distribution of UV chemical filters and H O 2 concentrations, exist in coastal waters, with the highest concentrations of UV-filters measured in the surface microlayer (SML) (Sánchez-Quiles and Tovar-Sánchez, 2014; Tovar-Sánchez et al., 2013) . According to these authors, concentrations of chemicals in the first centimeter of the sea surface water (SML) were up to 41.5% for BZ-3, 43.0% for 4-MBC and 41.6% for H O 2 higher than in the Giokas et al., 2005; (9) Giokas et al., 2004; (10) Goksøyr et al., 2009; (11) Gómez et al., 2009; (12) Jurado et al., 2014; (13) Kameda et al., 2011; (14) Kasprzyk-Hordern et al., 2008; (15) Kawaguchi et al., 2008; (16) Lambropoulou et al., 2002; (17) Langford and Thomas, 2008; (18) Li et al., 2007; (19) Magi et al., 2012; (20) Nguyen et al., 2011; (21) Pedrouzo et al., 2010; (22) Pedrouzo et al., 2009; (23) Pintado-Herrera et al., 2013; (24) Poiger et al., 2004; (25) Rodil et al., 2009a; (26) Rodil et al., 2009c; (27) Tarazona et al., 2010; (28) Tashiro and Kameda, 2013; (29) Tovar-Sánchez et al., 2013; (30) Trenholm et al., 2008; (31) Tsui et al., 2014; (32) Vidal et al., 2010; (33) Wick et al., 2010 ; River water (river and stream); n.d. (no detected); WWTP (waste water treatment plant). ⁎ Including surface microlayer.
body_text.section: The role of sunscreens as source of pollutants into coastal waters

body_text.text: immediately subsurface waters. Because of its lipophilicity (e.g. log K ow of 3.79 and 4.95 for BZ-3 and 4-MBC, respectively) these compounds tend to accumulate in the SML (Tovar-Sánchez et al., 2013) and in muscle and adipose tissues of marine organisms (Gago-Ferrero et al., 2012) . To our knowledge, few studies address the environmental implications of the total composition of sunscreens. The first study that provided the toxic effect of sunscreens in the marine environment was carried out by Danovaro and Corinaldesi (2003) , who demonstrated that sunscreens induce viral infections and control marine bacterioplankton. The same authors demonstrated that sunscreens induce corals bleaching by promoting the lytic viral cycle, killing the symbiotic microalgae zooxanthellae (Danovaro et al., 2008) .
body_text.section: OMC

body_text.text: The toxic effects of sunscreens and their main components have opened a debate about the regulation and labeling of sunscreens. In accordance with their chemical composition (Sobek et al., 2013) suggested that sunscreens should be labeled according to the European Union CLP regulation (classification, labeling and packaging; EC 1272/ 2008). Therefore sunscreens with ingredients that could be a risk for the marine environment (e.g. nano-TiO 2 ), should be labeled with hazard statements or even labeled with hazard pictograms, as occurs with other products that include the same components, such as paints. On the other hand, the Environmental Working Group (EWG) affirms that sunscreens with inorganic UV-filters would be a better choice for the marine environment than those with organic UV-filters (EWG, 2014), although they are aware that the effects of nanoparticles on the environment remain unknown. Because of the effects of nanoparticles on the marine ecosystem are not fully understood, Jacobs et al. (2010) considered that the use of these nanoparticles in sunscreens is morally unacceptable. Consequently, investigations of sunscreens with "environmental-friendly" formulations have increased in the last years (Danovaro et al., 2014) . Since many organisms in nature have developed its own photoprotective mechanisms the use of natural components is being explored. Several types of secondary metabolites are known to act as sunscreens in plants and animals, such as melanin (in humans), scytonemin (in cyanobacteria), mycosporine and mycosporine-like amino acids (MAA's) (with an wide phylogenetic distribution) and carotenoids which biosynthesis can be UVB-inducible in cyanobacteria (Gao and Garcia-Pichel, 2011 , and references therein).
body_text.section: OMC

body_text.text: The world coastal-zone population is expected to grow from 1.2 billion people (in 1990) up to 5.2 billion by 2080 (Rabalais et al., 2009) . According to the Word Tourism Organization (WTO), the Mediterranean coast received almost 30% of world international tourist arrivals in 2013 (UNWTO World Tourism Barometer, 2014). With 220 million of tourists per year the Mediterranean region is one of the most visited destinations in the world, and half of these visitors go en masse to the Mediterranean beaches (WWF Global, 2014. http://www.mediterranean. panda.org/threats). Moreover, it has been estimated that the Mediterranean region could receive up to 264 million tourists in 2030 (World Tourism Organization UNWTO, 2011). Spain is the country that is most clearly experiencing this growth. In Spain, tourism is one of the mainstays of the country's economy. It accounts for around 11% of GDP and 13% of employment, and contributes substantially to offsetting the trade deficit. With a new record of foreign visitors (i.e. 64.9 million in 2014) (Turespaña, 2015. http://www.iet. tourspain.es), this country has consolidated its position as the secondlargest worldwide destination (in the OECD countries: organization for Economic Co-operation and Development) in terms of tourist arrivals and receipts. Tourist arrivals have increased by 93% in the period 2004 (OECD Tourism Trends and Policies, 2010 , with more than 50% of arrivals concentrated in the Mediterranean coasts (Catalonia, Balearic Islands and Valencia) (Mantiñán and Solla, 2010) . In fact, the Balearic Islands is one of the most important tourist destinations in the Mediterranean Sea (Cirer-Costa, 2012). The international tourist arrivals are increasing every year, with more than 11 million tourist arrivals in 2013, mostly concentrated during summer season (Turespaña, 2015. http://www.iet.tourspain.es). In fact, it is considered like a second generation European mass tourist resort (Knowles and Curtis, 1999) . With a 1.1 million of inhabitants, this influx of visitors increases by more than 10 times the normal population of the islands.
body_text.section: Coastal tourism trend and use of sunscreen: the Spain case

body_text.text: Associated with the growth of tourism activities, sun-care products present the fastest growing sales globally, with Western Europe as the largest market. Sun protection is the most important segment of the sun care market with almost € 7.0 billion forecasted in 2014, a worldwide increase of 7% per year over the last five years, and with an average per capita consumption of 20 mL per year (Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Despite the high diversity of sunscreens (e.g. lotions, spray, roll-on, shake well types, etc.) lotions and creams represent approximately 60% of the total products introduced into the market. Spray format is also very popular in Europe with 20% presence in the market. Sunscreens with Solar Protection Factor (SPF) between 30 and 50 are produced in high quantities, and they represent the 50-60% (Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Spain is the country with the highest consumption of sunscreen per capita with 189 mL per year in 2012 (Osterwalder et al., 2014) . Considering its pupolation of 47 million it represent a consumption of almost 9 million liters of sunscreen per year. According to a survey carried out in Spain, almost 80% of the population used sunscreen to protect their skin against the UV radiation (Galán et al., 2011) . This percentage is significantly higher than in the United Kingdom (37%) (Miles et al., 2005) or Australia (27%) (Dobbinson et al., 2008) .
body_text.section: Coastal tourism trend and use of sunscreen: the Spain case

body_text.text: It is, therefore particularly challenging to assess the impact of sunscreens on the marine environment and prevent and/or reduce the effects of these emerging pollutants on the coastal ecosystems.
body_text.section: Coastal tourism trend and use of sunscreen: the Spain case

body_text.text: This review evaluates the environmental implications of commercial sunscreens and their main components as a source of chemicals in the coastal ecosystem. Results presented here indicate that the main components of sunscreens (organic and inorganic UV filters) reach coastal seawater and other recreational waters (i.e. lakes) with potential ecological consequences on the ecosystem. Once in the water column, components released from sunscreens accumulate in different environmental compartments (i.e. SML, biota and sediments) and may be bioconcentrated and/or bioaccumulated in the food web. Organic and inorganic UV-filters could be photodegradated by-products or photoexcited by sunlight generating elevated concentrations of reactive oxygen species with toxic effects on phytoplankton. Other components released from sunscreen (i.e. NO 3 − , NO 2 − , PO 4 3− , SiO 2 and NH 4 + ) are easily dissolved in seawater and may stimulate algal growth (Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: Conclusions and future perspectives

body_text.text: Associated to data of coastal-zone population growth and tourism activities, sun-care products present the fastest growing sales globally, with the Western Mediterranean countries as the largest market. This fact together with recent research indicating the presence and accumulation of sunscreen products in environmental compartments highlight the potential risk that the increasing use of these cosmetics would have in the coastal marine areas. However, future investigations are needed to understand the magnitude and real impact of these emerging pollutants in the marine system, such as distribution and partitioning in the water column, dissolution and speciation of their main components, evaluation of the ecological significance of the input of nutrients, residence time and aging, persistence, accumulation and toxicity in the trophic chain. Additional ecotoxicological experiments are also needed to better understand the effects of these products in the marine environment. For example, new studies could evaluate the stress level and species succession in marine phyto-and zooplankton, and commercial and endangered coastal marine species (e.g. seagrasses, bivalves, fishes, etc). The nearshore habitat of these marine plants, together with many other pelagic and benthic fauna, are affected by sunscreens and therefore its impact should be addressed.
